Situation1: They are asked to take an active role in leading a significant family ceremony to preserve tradition.
Expectation2: Maintain a safe and O39ean work environment.
Situation2: At the end of the shift, it's time for the routine sweep-up of your designated work area.
Story: I could hear my mother’s voice on the phone, her words heavy with hope and pride. “You’ll lead the ceremony this year, won’t you? It means so much to your grandmother.” I promised her I would be there, that I’d honor our family’s traditions just as she had. But as I hung up, the foreman’s whistle cut through the air, signaling the end of our shift. My boots were caked with dust, and the site was a mess—nails, boards, and debris scattered everywhere. Safety rules were strict; every worker had to leave their area spotless, or risk penalties for the whole crew. My coworkers were already grabbing brooms, glancing at me expectantly. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing down on me: my family counting on me to uphold our heritage, my team relying on me to keep the site safe and clean. My heart pounded as I stared at my phone, torn between the pull of home and the demands of the job, knowing I couldn’t be in two places at once.
